challenges.description:
Mitiga Solutions provides risk assessment insights on events related to climate change. 
In Mitiga, I am part of a multidisciplinary team, and in charge of designing solutions to generate, tranform and serve our data (ETL pipelines and microservice architecture). 
I work mainly with Python in my day to day. Also Argo as a workflow orchestrator and Azure as cloud provider.
I also try to step out of my box and use my experience to streamline and improve other sides of the company. A couple of examples are the improvement of our onboarding, the developer experience and applying GitOps paradigm to the deployment of our workflows.

Plantix is the #1 app for crop disease detection. With the help of AI, it is helping millions of small scale farmers increasing their yields and improving their knowledge with a single picture taken with their mobile phones.

Software Engineer at the Converters Control Software section, a unit of the Electrical Power Converters group at CERN. Our section is in charge of the development and maintenance of software to control around 5000 power converters distributed across the accelerator chain at CERN.  I mainly write software for our in-house embedded platform (C), and I am also responsible for our section's transition from Perl (due to a large legacy code base) to Python. In this last language I have also written libraries to communicate with our control devices and 3-tier layer applications to reprogram custom electronics.  I have also recruited and supervised young engineers for diverse projects, one of them being the design and development of our new in-house next generation of embedded controls platform.  This role also involves project management and coordination, during the Long Shutdown 2, of activities with different distributed teams that affect O(1000) equipments, and 24/7 on-call support.

organization.name: University of Wisconsin-Madison, based at CERN

roles.name: Software developer in the L1 Trigger Online SW group; CMS experiment.

challenges.description: The CMS experiment is one of the four main particle detectors at CERN. It is a large international collaboration of different research institutes and universities. The Level-1 Trigger performs a coarse selection of the most relevant physics events from a data stream of about 80 TB/s.  As part of the Level-1 Trigger Central Online SW group, I was responsible for the development and maintenance of common components that are key in CMS day to day operations and used by a community of ~ 30 developers (mainly C++). Other projects involved full-stack software development for applications monitoring and configuring the Level-1 Trigger components (Javascript/HTML, Java and C++ as backend languages and Oracle SQL databases). I was also responsible for providing to different development groups with the necessary infrastructure to ensure a smooth and high quality software development cycle, as well as offering support and consultancy services for bugs resolution and tasks development.   Other: 24/7 SW on-call expert, student supervisor.

Within the Communication Systems IT group, I was responsible for CERN’s mobile phone and VHF networks, with ~ 5000 and ~ 50 users respectively, and their monitoring system based on GSM probes. As the main contact at CERN, I followed up closely different projects with our service provider.

Joined the CERN IT/CS group with the responsibility of designing a system to perform remote configuration of mobile phones for GPRS access. It consisted on a  GPRS/SMS modem installed on a Linux server and the control SW developed in Perl.

manfredSpecificData.desiredJobDescription:
At the risk of sounding rather corny, my dream job is the one that allows me use my skills to improve things around me, ideally in health, climate change or education areas.
I enjoy having a mixture of tasks in my working day/week: I really love designing and developing solutions behind the curtains (backend, yey!), also speaking with clients of our solutions to understand better what they need, coordinating actions between teams towards a common goal and streamlining complicated processes that make our day to day difficult, tiring and tedious.
manfredSpecificData.goodPractices:
Testing! I have worked in different projects where testing was insufficient, so I have spent time adding it.
This also has the benefit of being able to refactor with more protection than keeping your fingers crossed.

Also peer reviewing and making sure the team has the appropriate infrastructure to have a smooth development cycle.
